description: From an earlier tardive, from French tardif, from Late Latin tardīvus, from Latin tardus (“slow”, “sluggish”), of obscure origin.

examples: He yawned, then raised a tardy hand over his mouth.

entries.meaning: Moving with a slow pace or motion; not swift.
examples: These berries  […]  are a deadly and insidious poison, though very tardy in their action, often lying dormant in the blood for many days.

entries.meaning: Ineffectual; slow-witted, slow to act, or dull.
examples: His tardy performance bordered on incompetence.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Unwary; unready (especially in the phrase take (someone) tardy).

examples: And the Franks served the Men much the same ſauce when they found them tardy, and made them run their Heats through the Streets

entries.meaning: (US) A piece of paper given to students who are late to class.
examples: The teacher gave her a tardy because she did not come into the classroom until after the bell.

entries.meaning: (US) An instance of a student's being marked as tardy by a teacher on the teacher's attendance sheet.

verbs.description: tardy (third-person singular simple present tardies, present participle tardying, simple past and past participle tardied)
